Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Multiscale Mechanical Models for the Aging Brain

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
As 81 million 'baby boomers' living in the US enter old age, the fact that 50 percent of adults over the age of 85 are afflicted with Alzheimer's disease presents a looming crisis. Early diagnosis or the hope of developing an effective neuroprotective or regenerative intervention requires a deeper understanding of how the healthy human brain ages normally. A novel noninvasive elastography method based on magnetic resonance imaging has allowed high-resolution measurements of local mechanical properties of the living brain, which reveal that brain stiffness decreases with age. This award focuses on the development of fundamental knowledge to connect brain tissue microstructure with local mechanical properties measured noninvasively. Employing imaging technology available in the local clinic, mechanical maps of the brain can then be generated and used as a baseline to determine the stage of age-related brain degeneration, or to monitor the efficacy of an intervention. This award will enhance the outreach efforts of both principal investigators towards continuing to attract engineers from traditionally underrepresented groups interested in the intersection of computational mechanics, soft-tissue mechanics, image processing, and neuroscience. In addition to the enrichment of the mechanics-related curriculum and training of future engineers in research aligned with the national healthy brain initiatives, this project is expected to directly impact the broader medical communities at the two institutions.

Two important technical advances have provided insight into the development and degeneration of brain neurons: cell-level mechanobiology and high-resolution in vivo magnetic resonance elastography. The challenge is to unify these two levels of analysis in order to obtain a rigorous biomechanical view of the white matter of the human brain during normal aging. This award supports the development of hierarchical multiscale models of white matter micromechanics based on medical imaging and published histological data. These models will enable the interpretation of the magnetic resonance elastography data in terms of certain parameters in axon microstructure. Local viscoelastic properties will be spatially correlated with architectural metrics of the axonal network, so that the biomechanical properties of the brain can be investigated across subjects and age groups. The main outcome of this multiscale modeling effort is to relate the structural integrity of the axons to locally averaged functional properties quantified by magnetic resonance imaging. This will help explain how the age-related changes in the brain white matter are related to alterations in connectivity and mechanical coupling between neurons and glial cells as they age.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With the life expectancy of the 80 million ?baby boomers? currently living in the US increasing, so is the threat of a cognitive decline or dementia to the quality of life. Since 50% of adults over the age of 85 are afflicted with Alzheimer?s Disease, diagnosing and developing therapeutic interventions for the pathological cases requires a deeper understanding of how the human brain ages normally. Two important technical advances have provided insight into the development and degeneration of brain neurons: cell-level micromechanics and high-resolution in vivo magnetic resonance elastography (MRE). The challenge addressed in this collaborative research endeavor is the unification of these two levels of analysis in order to obtain a rigorous biomechanical view of the white matter of the human brain during normal aging. In the past, our group has made a significant improvement in both the spatial resolution and accuracy of ΜRΕ, and reported detailed 3D maps of viscoelastic properties of the healthy human brain in vivo with unprecedented resolution. The use of isotropic tissue models based on properties that do not vary with the direction of mechanical excitation (NLI) reveals that brain stiffness decreases with age. Since we found that these variations change with the direction that the brain is excited mechanically, the tissue models used to interpret MRE data (inversion method) need to be revisited. The companion project involved the systematic development of appropriate (anisotropic) multiscale models of white matter micromechanics starting from the microstructure. The present project demonstrated the use of this anisotropic tissue model and inversion method in certain white matter areas, such as the human corpus callosum (figure 1(a)).

 

We incorporated MRE data from two-direction excitation (figure 1(b)) and diffusion tensor imaging (DTI) data (figure 1(d)) in a novel iterative scheme (Inverse Transversely Isotropic, ITI). ITI allows the estimation of shear moduli parallel and perpendicular to the local axon direction (figure 1(c)). We then compared the regional average values between the two cohorts of healthy young (24-32 years old) and older (55-76 years old) adults. We averaged the mechanical properties over a volume centered on the body of the corpus callosum of each subject (figure 1(a)). We found that the anisotropic model (ITI) accentuates the difference between young and old groups in terms of viscoelastic properties, relative to the isotropic model (NLI). Both models show decrease of storage moduli with age, but the ITI shows decrease of both storage and loss moduli. Both models show higher ratio of loss to storage moduli for the old group, but the ITI model enhances those differences. In summary, the extracted mechanical properties are dramatically different from those extracted via NLI from the same multi-excitation data, allowing the detection of statistically significant differences in white matter viscoelasticity with age. This study underlines the importance of accurately modeling certain brain white matter regions by anisotropic tissue models.

This project focused on the development of fundamental knowledge to connect brain tissue microstructure with regional mechanical properties measured noninvasively. Employing imaging technology available in the local clinic, mechanical maps of the brain can then be generated and used as a baseline to determine the stage of age-related brain degeneration, or to monitor the efficacy of an intervention. This award enabled the contribution of different specialties interested in the intersection of computational mechanics, soft-tissue mechanics, image processing, and neuroscience. In addition to the enrichment of the mechanics-related curriculum and training of future engineers in research aligned with the national healthy brain initiatives, this collaborative project is expected to directly impact the broader medical communities among the three institutions who participated.
